content:
**TRUE**.

The 2023 Winter Universiade, officially known as the Lake Placid 2023 FISU World University Games, was held in Lake Placid, New York, United States[1][2][3].

## Host City Confirmation

Lake Placid was officially confirmed as the host for the 31st edition of the winter event on August 16, 2018[4][5]. The International University Sports Federation (FISU) completed the Host City Contract signing in Lausanne, Switzerland, after then-New York Governor Andrew M. Cuomo signed an Executive Order authorizing Lake Placid and the surrounding North Country Region to host the games[6][4][7].

Lake Placid was the sole candidate for the event, and its bid was characterized by FISU President Oleg Matytsin as "one of the strongest we have seen"[6].

## Event Details

The games took place from January 12 to January 22, 2023[1][8][9]. The competition featured 1,417 collegiate athletes between the ages of 17 and 25, representing 47 nations[10][9]. Initial projections anticipated more than 3,000 total participants, including student-athletes, delegates, and officials from 60 countries and 600 universities[4][5].

While Lake Placid served as the main host city, events were also held in the neighboring communities of Wilmington, Saranac Lake, Potsdam, and North Creek[1]. Venues included the historic Herb Brooks Arena, site of the "Miracle on Ice" at the 1980 Olympics, which hosted the 2023 finals for ice hockey[4][11].

## Historical Context

This marked the second time Lake Placid has hosted the Winter Universiade, having previously held the 7th edition of the games in 1972[6][4][12]. This made it the first city to host the Winter World University Games twice[13]. Lake Placid also has a significant Olympic history, having hosted the Winter Olympics in 1932 and 1980[6][13]. The 2023 games were the first time the winter event was held in the United States in 51 years[12].
